channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Outspoken billionaire Sun Dawu jailed for 18 years in China
item.description: Sun Dawu has in the past been vocal in criticising authorities and has spoken out about human rights.

item.title: Simone Biles thankful for love and support
item.description: US gymnast Simone Biles reacts to the widespread support she has received after withdrawing from Thursday's all-around final.

item.title: US: China interest in Afghanistan could be positive
item.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's comments came after Taliban envoys went on a visit to China.

item.title: Global education summit targets pandemic-hit schooling
item.description: A summit in London is raising aid to support 175 million children in the poorest countries.

item.title: Covid vaccines: Tourists head to the US to get vaccinated
item.description: Some tourists are spending thousands of dollars to travel to the US to get a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Israel investigating shooting of Palestinian boy in West Bank
item.description: Palestinian officials say soldiers shot the 12-year-old as he travelled in a car in the West Bank.

item.title: Actor Bob Odenkirk 'stable' after collapsing on set
item.description: The US actor is still in hospital after being rushed there from the set of Better Call Saul.

item.title: Netflix US cast and crew must be vaccinated to work
item.description: The online streaming firm is the latest company to make Covid jabs mandatory for workers.

item.title: Colorado officer arrested after threatening to shoot suspect during stop
item.description: The Colorado officer was filmed striking a man with his gun, saying "if you move, I will shoot you".

item.title: Bosnian Serbs defy top UN official Inzko over genocide denial
item.description: Ethnic Serb leaders accused of playing down the Srebrenica massacre will now boycott parliament.

item.title: Arthur: Popular children's show to end after 25 years
item.description: US public broadcaster PBS confirmed the final episode will air in winter 2022.

item.title: Dusty Hill: ZZ Top bassist dies aged 72
item.description: Dusty Hill played bass for the iconic US blues rock band for more than five decades.

item.title: South Africa riots: The inside story of Durban's week of anarchy
item.description: The worst unrest since white-minority rule ended has left deep scars, especially in the coastal city of Durban.

item.title: Why cannabis is still a banned Olympics substance
item.description: US sprinter Sha'carri Richardson won't compete due to a positive marijuana test. People are asking why.

item.title: Pedro Castillo: The primary school teacher who became Peru's president
item.description: The meteoric rise of leftist Pedro Castillo has shaken Peru's political and business elite.

item.title: Gaza photographer hopes digital art boom can help raise aid money
item.description: A Palestinian photographer wants to help children by selling an image from May's conflict.

item.title: Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue and his love of Bugattis and Michael Jackson
item.description: Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue, tipped as Equatorial Guinea's next leader, is under sanctions in the UK and France.

item.title: Petrol bombs thrown at Cuban embassy in Paris
item.description: Cuba's foreign ministry has released surveillance footage of the attack at its embassy in France.

item.title: Capitol Hill police officer in tears during testimony
item.description: Officer Gonell gave an emotional statement during the first day of the US Capitol riot inquiry.

item.title: Lebanon’s descent into darkness
item.description: The country's economic crisis has forced some families to move into refugee camps to survive.

item.title: Roma student: 'My only goal is to finish school'
item.description: How one school in Croatia is working to improve education opportunities for Roma children like Kristina.

item.title: Dad builds robotic exoskeleton to help son walk
item.description: The French robotics engineer says he was inspired to build the suit after his son asked him to.

item.title: Simone Biles: What are the twisties in gymnastics?
item.description: US gymnast Simone Biles said she was "having a little bit of the twisties".

item.title: Tokyo Olympics rowing: Ireland's Paul O'Donovan & Fintan McCarthy win lightweight men's double sculls
item.description: Ireland win their first gold medal of the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games as Paul O'Donovan and Fintan McCarthy claim the lightweight men's double sculls.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Take a tour of the incredible venues
item.description: They range from an arena built by a father and son, to a legendary home of Japanese martial arts.

item.title: From garden pool to Olympic gold
item.description: Matt Richards' relay swim team almost broke the world record as they won gold in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics medals table
item.description: Medals table for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: German gymnasts' full-body suits inspire other athletes
item.description: British-Jamaican gymnast Danusia Francis believes athletes should have a choice over their outfits.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Flora Duffy claims historic first gold for Bermuda
item.description: With a population of just 63,000, Bermuda became the least populous nation or territory to win an Olympic gold medal at a summer Games when Flora Duffy won the triathlon in Tokyo.

item.title: Wright wins first ever Olympic surfing medal
item.description: Australian surfer Owen Wright marks his comeback from a traumatic brain injury by winning the first ever Olympic medal in surfing.
